title: World Happiness Report Analysis
tagline: What drives happiness across countries? A data story using Tableau + Python.

overview.what: Analyzed global happiness data (2005–2023) to understand how life satisfaction varies by country and what factors are most strongly linked to happiness.
overview.why: Organizations and governments want to improve well-being, but happiness is influenced by multiple economic and social factors — not just income.
overview.soWhat: The results suggest that policies combining economic stability with stronger social systems are more likely to improve happiness outcomes.

keyQuestions: How does happiness vary across countries and regions?
Which factors are most strongly associated with higher happiness?
Can countries be grouped into meaningful segments using clustering?
How can these insights support better policy decisions?

methodology.summary: Mapped happiness globally and explored distributions and trends over time.
Tested relationships between happiness, GDP per capita, and social support.
Grouped countries into segments based on happiness, GDP per capita, and social support.

highlights.title: Happiness is strongly linked to social support
highlights.detail: Countries with stronger social support systems tend to report higher happiness — even beyond income levels.
highlights.soWhat: Investing in social systems can raise well-being outcomes alongside economic growth.

highlights.title: GDP matters, but it’s not the full story
highlights.detail: Higher GDP per capita is generally associated with higher happiness, but it does not explain everything.
highlights.soWhat: Economic growth alone may not meaningfully improve life satisfaction without social stability.

highlights.title: Three meaningful country clusters emerge
highlights.detail: Clustering separates countries into low, mid, and high well-being segments based on happiness + GDP + social support.
highlights.soWhat: These segments can guide targeted policy strategies rather than using one-size-fits-all solutions.

clusters.name: Cluster 1: Low GDP + Low Social Support
clusters.profile: Lower happiness levels and weaker support systems.
clusters.soWhat: Policy focus: foundational stability — jobs, safety nets, basic services.

clusters.name: Cluster 2: Moderate GDP + Moderate Social Support
clusters.soWhat: Policy focus: strengthen institutions and social support to lift well-being.

clusters.name: Cluster 3: High GDP + Strong Social Support
clusters.profile: Highest happiness levels and strong social support.
clusters.soWhat: Policy focus: maintain quality of life and address inequality/mental health.

visualizations.title: Visualizations
visualizations.subtitle: A mix of global views, relationships, and model-backed segmentation.

items.title: Global Happiness Heatmap
items.subtitle: A country-level view of happiness scores across the world.
items.soWhat: Quickly reveals high/low well-being regions and where to investigate deeper.

items.title: Happiness vs GDP per Capita
items.subtitle: How income relates to happiness across countries.
items.soWhat: Shows that wealth generally helps — but it doesn’t fully explain happiness differences.

items.title: Happiness vs Social Support
items.subtitle: Relationship between social support and life satisfaction.
items.soWhat: Highlights social support as a consistently strong driver of happiness.

items.title: Country Segments (Clustering View)
items.subtitle: Country groups based on happiness, GDP, and social support.
items.soWhat: Useful for tailoring strategies by segment instead of treating all countries the same.

recommendations.title: Balance economic and social investments
recommendations.detail: Don’t rely only on GDP growth — strengthen social support systems too.

recommendations.title: Use segmentation for targeted policy
recommendations.detail: Different clusters need different interventions (basic stability vs. quality-of-life improvements).

recommendations.title: Focus on holistic well-being drivers
recommendations.detail: Consider healthcare, education, trust, and work-life balance alongside economic measures.

nextSteps: Add variables like inequality, governance quality, and freedom of choice.
Test non-linear or multivariate models to capture more complex relationships.
Refine clustering with more features to improve segmentation.
limitations: Happiness scores are self-reported and may include cultural bias.
Some countries/years have missing data which can affect comparisons.
